Except for a new level 2 fire that appeared this afternoon and forced the evacuation of the town of Berlanga del Bierzo in Leon, the general situation is positive, with a favorable evolution of the Fasgar-Igüeña fire in Bierzo, and no fires larger than 20 hectares active in Galicia.


The improvement in the weather conditions, with a drop in temperatures and the rain that has fallen in some areas, has allowed the teams to advance in the work of extinguishing many of the fires.
According to forecasts, the danger remains extreme because of "the cumulative rate" of the areas of large fires and, in addition, the weather conditions will not be so favorable from tomorrow, Friday, has warned the director general of Civil Protection, Virginia Barcones.

The latest updated data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) put the number of hectares burned in a total of 276 fires so far this year at 394,398.
Since this latest wave of fires began on August 8, 35,691 people have had to be evacuated from their homes, 53 people have been arrested for possible links to the fires and 140 have been investigated, according to the State Coordination Committee (Cecod).
A new fire in Castilla y León
A forest fire declared on Thursday afternoon, classified as level 2 by the Junta de Castilla y León, has caused the evacuation of the town of Berlanga del Bierzo (León), of 300 inhabitants .
The fire started around 17.30 hours and maintains deployed 17 means of extinction, including four helicopters, several seaplanes and two fire engines, in addition to ground troops, according to the Ministry of Environment.

In relation to this fire, the Civil Guard has arrested a young man of 20 years as the alleged perpetrator of a crime of arson, as there was will and premeditation.
As for the fire of Fasgar-Igueña, the most worrying at this time nationwide, remains active, but its evolution in recent hours has been more favorable, reported the technical director of extinction of this fire, Agustin Argulo.

The focus of concern remains in the east, where two additional control lines have been established, especially in the vicinity of Espina de Tremor, to "prevent the fire from spreading through the steep terrain, difficult to access for ground crews."
The western area, towards Colinas del Campo de Martín Moro Toledano, and the south, towards Igueña, already present cooler temperatures and controlled hot spots.
Galicia, no active fires
In Galicia there is no active fire of more than 20 hectares this Thursday for the first time since the wave of fires began this August, after those in A Pobra do Brollón (Lugo), of about 900 hectares, and Avión (Ourense), of 250 hectares, have been stabilized.
The great wave of fires that the community has suffered this August has devastated 96,000 hectares, according to the figures of the Xunta, most of them in the province of Ourense, so that 2025 is already the year with more extension burned in Galicia this century.
There are no roads closed to traffic and, as for the railway service, the circulation between Monforte de Lemos and San Clodio-Quiroga, on the Monforte-Ponferrada line, remains interrupted.
On the other hand, the fire of Carballeda de Valdeorras-Casaio, with 5,000 hectares burned and which entered the Galician community from Porto de Sanabria (Zamora), has improved and has passed to controlled, while that of A Fonsagrada (Lugo) has been extinguished after burning 53.47 hectares.
The Larouco fire (Ourense), the largest in the history of Galicia with 30,000 hectares burned, is under control, as are two of the three outbreaks in Chandrexa de Queixa (19,000 ha), while the outbreak in Vilariño remains stabilized.
Only one active fire in Asturias
Asturias has registered this Thursday six forest fires, one active in Ibias, three stabilized in Degaña, Genestoso in Cangas del Narcea and Caunedo/Gúa/Perlunes in Somiedo and two controlled in Cabrales and Tineo, reported the Emergency Service of the Principality.
In the case of the Ibias fire, the operative has worked throughout the day watering the smoldering points with aerial means, while a backhoe has acted on the flanks of the fire.

Kolkata, Sep 4 (IANS) The West Bengal government has listed heatwave deaths as a natural disaster, and will provide financial assistance of Rs 2 lakh to the affected family.



This decision was taken in a recent meeting of the 'State Executive Committee', said sources in the state secretariat on Thursday.

In the last few years, several deaths due to heatstroke were reported across the state. The deaths were reported from districts, including western districts of Purulia, Bankura, West Midnapore, Jhargram, West Burdwan and Birbhum, which witness heatwave or heatwave conditions during summer.

"The government officials took notice of such incidents and started thinking about this," said the sources. In August, state Chief Secretary Manoj Pant held a meeting on this. It is reported that in that meeting, it was decided to provide financial assistance in case of death due to heatstroke as a result of a heatwave.

The government will soon be issuing a formal notification in this regard, said the sources.

In case of a death due to the heatwave, a post-mortem report will be mandatory to get financial assistance. Once it is established that the person died due to heatstroke, then only the family will receive the compensation.

The money will be released only after verifying the cause of the death.

According to a government official, declaring heatwave deaths as natural disasters will now make it possible to provide this compensation from the State Disaster Response Fund (SDRF). About 10 per cent of the annual allocation of the SDRF can be used to provide compensation to the families of those who died in natural disasters, the official added.

It may be noted that the state government till now provides compensation of Rs 2 lakh in cases of death due to lightning strike, accidental fire, boat capsizing, falling trees and wall collapse of a house.

From now on, the state government declared 14 incidents, including heatwave, river erosion, heavy rain, wild animal attack, death due to electrocution, forest fire, death due to venomous animal bite or animal attack as natural disasters.

Cusco: Unsaac closed for 48 hours due to university teachers' protest.Preventive strike demands compliance with University Law 30220, higher budget, payment of CTS, respect and better working conditions for teachers and practice managers.

Rains and brigadiers manage to control forest fire in Machu Picchu

Luis Alvarez
The National University of San Antonio Abad del Cusco (Unsaac) dawned this Wednesday with its doors closed. The teachers' union of the university, headed by its leader Olinto Aguilar, complied in a disciplined manner with the 48-hour preventive strike called by the National Federation of University Teachers of Peru (Fendup).


Aguilar explained that the measure responds to the non-compliance with University Law 30220, which guarantees a larger budget for public higher education. "Laboratories, cabinets and classrooms that should be state-of-the-art are neglected. Meanwhile, teachers continue to be the only sector of the public administration that does not have Compensation for Time of Service (CTS)," he said.
The leader denounced that, in spite of the requirement of a law passed last year, the CTS regulation has not yet been implemented, leaving hundreds of teachers in the uncertainty of retiring without a fair compensation. While in other sectors workers receive more than 200 thousand soles for this concept, a university professor would barely receive around seven thousand soles.
He also criticized the precariousness of the salaries: "A senior professor can receive around eight thousand soles, but after deductions there is much less. And in the case of associate professors, assistants or practice managers, some earn even less than the minimum wage, despite having master's degrees, doctorates and years of service".
Local platform
Aguilar also questioned the university authorities for prioritizing investments in administrative infrastructure instead of attending to academic demands. "More than 100 million has been allocated in a building for bureaucracy, while the halls, laboratories and classrooms remain abandoned," he pointed out.
During the 48 hours of stoppage, there will be no academic or administrative activities at the Perayoq university headquarters. This caused uneasiness among students and users.

Kolkata, Sep 4 (IANS) The West Bengal government has listed heatwave deaths as a natural disaster, and will provide financial assistance of Rs 2 lakh to the affected family.This decision was taken in a recent meeting of the 'State Executive Committee', said sources in the state secretariat on Thursday.


In the last few years, several deaths due to heatstroke were reported across the state. The deaths were reported from districts, including western districts of Purulia, Bankura, West Midnapore, Jhargram, West Burdwan and Birbhum, which witness heatwave or heatwave conditions during summer.
"The government officials took notice of such incidents and started thinking about this," said the sources. In August, state Chief Secretary Manoj Pant held a meeting on this. It is reported that in that meeting, it was decided to provide financial assistance in case of death due to heatstroke as a result of a heatwave.
The government will soon be issuing a formal notification in this regard, said the sources.
In case of a death due to the heatwave, a post-mortem report will be mandatory to get financial assistance. Once it is established that the person died due to heatstroke, then only the family will receive the compensation.
The money will be released only after verifying the cause of the death.
According to a government official, declaring heatwave deaths as natural disasters will now make it possible to provide this compensation from the State Disaster Response Fund (SDRF). About 10 per cent of the annual allocation of the SDRF can be used to provide compensation to the families of those who died in natural disasters, the official added.
It may be noted that the state government till now provides compensation of Rs 2 lakh in cases of death due to lightning strike, accidental fire, boat capsizing, falling trees and wall collapse of a house.
From now on, the state government declared 14 incidents, including heatwave, river erosion, heavy rain, wild animal attack, death due to electrocution, forest fire, death due to venomous animal bite or animal attack as natural disasters.

Finance Minister Nate Horner’s February budget pegged the deficit at $5.2 billion, but the first-quarter update now puts the shortfall at $6.5 billion.

Total revenue is forecast at about $73 billion, against $79 billion in expenses.

“We know the road ahead has its challenges, but with disciplined financial management and smart investments, we will stand by families, rein in the deficit and secure a stronger future,” said Horner, in a press release along with the update. “Careful fiscal management matters.”

According to the update, the biggest factor influencing the province’s budget is a 38 per cent drop in natural resource prices, which has resulted in a forecast revenue of $15.7 billion in 202526, down from $25.2 billion.

The price per barrel in 2025-26 is forecast at $63 USD, down from $89 in 2022.

Other factors influencing the province’s budget include a growing population, anticipated to increase by 2.4 per cent over the next year, tariff threats, and slowing global growth.

“Even with these challenges, Alberta remains committed to prioritizing essential services such as health care and education, while keeping everyday costs like childcare, utilities and housing affordable for families,” notes the release.

Included in Budget 202526 was a $4 billion contingency fund, of which $2.5 billion remains. Of the $1.5 billion allocated, over $700 million has been spent on disaster and emergency relief, $700 million on wildfire response, and $6 million on re-planting trees in forest fire-affected areas.

“Despite external shocks, Alberta’s economy remains resilient. Its real GDP is forecast to lead Canada, and the private sector continues to perform strongly with investment, construction and labour market activity supporting stability,” continues the release.

Alberta’s operating expense is forecast at $65 billion, $679 million more than budgeted, primarily due to public-sector wage growth.

The province is not alone in its budget woes; Saskatchewan is predicting a $349 million deficit after predicting a $12 million surplus, and New Brunswick’s deficit continues to climb, rising from $549 million to $668.7 million.

urn:contentItem:6GMJ-BM33-RS1W-G07D-00000-00IAEA says Russia blocks access to newly built dam at Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant2025-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisNUCLEAR POWER NEWS, Utilities news, Nuclear proliferation news, International relations news & RUSSIA NEWSIAEA says Russia blocks access to newly built dam at Zaporizhzhia nuclear plantBohdan Babaiev

IAEA experts have been unable to access a newly built dam on the channel of one of the cooling ponds at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant. Russian forces are preventing their entry, according to an IAEA report dated August 28.

"The IAEA team based at the ZNPP site - Europe's largest nuclear power plant (NPP) - continues to request access to the newly constructed dam but has not yet been permitted due to security concerns," the report said.

The dam was built to isolate one of the channels from a cooling pond and to help maintain water levels at around 14 meters. That level is sufficient to ensure the proper functioning of the reactors' cooling system.

"Our access to this dam is essential to assess the cooling water situation, which is crucial given the fragile nuclear safety situation at the ZNPP," IAEA Director General Rafael Grossi said.

IAEA experts were also denied entry to the western part of the machine hall of one of the reactors during a routine weekly inspection. In addition, the mission said it heard military activity in the vicinity of the facility.

Zaporizhzhia NPP under Russian occupation

The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, the largest in Ukraine and Europe, has been under Russian occupation since March 4, 2022. Russian troops have mined parts of the site and turned it into a military base. The facility has repeatedly faced the risk of blackouts due to Russian actions.

Russia is illegally detaining at least 13 employees of the plant. Seven have been sentenced on what the IAEA described as fabricated charges. Three others are awaiting verdicts in Russian prisons, while the fate of the remaining workers remains unknown.

On July 19, smoke was reported near the plant's cooling towers following a forest fire. The IAEA said the incident did not affect radiation levels.

urn:contentItem:6H0G-J9P3-RVC9-V36F-00000-00CLIMATE2025-10-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisMAIN NEWSNews DeskPart APg. 1CLIMATEBOILING POINTState's wildfire policy that overlooked SoCal is course correctingNoah Haggerty

At last month's meeting of the California Wildfire and Forest Resilience Task Force in Redlands, director Patrick Wright remembered the group's early days: "Candidly, when I started this job, we got an earful from Southern California."

Gov. Gavin Newsom created the task force in 2021 and at the time, Southern California's wildfire experts told Wright that he and other state leaders "didn't understand Southern California was different. Its vegetation is different. Its fire risk is different."

It's true -- the coastal chaparral native to much of Southern California is entirely different from the mixed-conifer forests of the Sierra.

More than a century of humans attempting to suppress nearly every fire meant the low-intensity burns that northern forests relied on every five to 20 years to promote regeneration no longer came through to clear the understory. As trees and shrubs grew in, they fueled high-intensity fires that decimated both the forest and communities.

Meanwhile in Southern California, as humans settled into the wildlands, they lighted more fires. Discarded cigarettes, sparking cars, poorly managed campfires, utility equipment and arsonists lighted up hundreds or thousands of acres. Here, the native chaparral is adapted to fire coming every 30 to 130 years. The more frequent fires didn't allow them to grow, make seeds and reproduce. Instead, what's grown in places where chaparral used to be are flammable invasive grasses.

But when I moved to Southern California and started covering the wildfires devastating our communities, I had heard only the northern version of the story.

The fire problem in Northern California is more widely understood.

"Smokey the Bear, only you can prevent forest fires -- everybody kind of knows, intuitively, what a forest fire is," said Michael O'Connell, president and chief executive of the Irvine Ranch Conservancy -- and one of the people who (respectfully) gave Wright an earful.

Meanwhile, ember-driven fires in Southern California are "like someone lobbing grenades from five miles away," he said.

Experts in NorCal and SoCal agree on how we ought to protect ourselves once a ferocious fire breaks out: Across the board, we need to harden our homes, create defensible space and ensure we're ready to evacuate. But how to prevent devastating fires differs.

The forest thinning and careful reintroduction of intentional "good" fire in the Sierra don't exactly translate to the Santa Monica Mountains, for example.

The problem here in the south is more vexing: How do we reduce the number of fires we spark?

One way is with groups like Orange County Fire Watch and Arson Watch in Topanga and Malibu, which go out on days when the wind is high and try to spot fires before they start. A new effort, celebrated by the task force, to reduce ignitions along SoCal roadways by clearing flammable vegetation is also underway.

But, although NorCal has a plethora of studies affirming the effectiveness of forest thinning and burning, there is little research yet on SoCal's proposed solutions.

"We really do, now, understand what the problem is that we're trying to deal with," O'Connell said. "How do you get that done? That's more complicated."

And the vast majority of state funding is still geared toward northern fuel management solutions -- not keeping fires from sparking. (The task force also still measures progress in acres treated, a largely meaningless metric for Southern California's chaparral.)

Yet, O'Connell is hopeful. At the task force's first meeting in SoCal -- where Wright got an earful -- leaders didn't yet have a grasp of SoCal's wildfire problem. Now, they're letting SoCal's land managers and researchers lead the way.

"If it weren't for the task force, I think we would be in big trouble, frankly," O'Connell said. The task force leaders "have not only understood [the problem] but have accepted it and run with that."

--

The latest on wildfires

Federal firefighters are in their third week without pay, as the U.S government shutdown drags on. According to the U.S. Forest Service -- the largest federal firefighting force in the country -- fire response personnel will continue to work through the shutdown, although prevention work, including prescribed burns and forest thinning, will be limited.

In the state, Newsom vetoed a bill that would increase the salaries of firefighters with the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection to more closely match those of local fire departments. Meanwhile, efforts championed by the state to build a series of fuel breaks in the Santa Monica Mountains are underway. Some ecologists worry about the damage the fast-moving project could do to the environment; others say the state is not moving fast enough.

Last week, federal prosecutors announced the arrest of a suspect they believed intentionally started the Palisades fire on Jan. 1. The announcement has led to calls for the Los Angeles Fire Department, responsible for putting out the Jan. 1 fire, and California State Parks, whose land the fire started on, to be held accountable.

--

And the latest on climate

A turning point and a tipping point: Global energy production turned a corner in the first half of the year, with renewables such as solar and wind generating more electricity than coal for the first time. And, the Earth is reaching its first climate change tipping point: Warm water coral reefs can no longer survive, according to a report published by 160 scientists.

With the 2025 state legislative session wrapped up, some important climate bills are now law. One law extends California's cap-and-trade program -- which limits how much greenhouse gas polluters can emit and enables them to trade emission allowances at auction -- from 2030 to 2045. Newsom also signed a bill to make oil drilling in Kern County easier while making offshore drilling more difficult and another to push local governments to increase electrification efforts.

Newsom vetoed a bill that would have required data centers to report how much water they use. He was "reluctant to impose rigid reporting requirements" on the centers, he wrote in a message explaining his veto, noting that "California is well positioned to support the development of this critically important digital infrastructure."

urn:contentItem:6GJT-YYR3-RRH2-X46B-00000-00Portugal wildfire kills fourth person as Spain sees relief from heat2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisPortugal wildfire kills fourth person as Spain sees relief from heatMadrid (dpa) -

A fourth person has died in Portugal while fighting the massive forest fires engulfing parts of the country, state television channel RTP reported on Saturday.

The firefighter suffered severe burns on Tuesday near the small town of Sabugal in eastern Portugal and died on Saturday in a hospital in Porto, RTP said.

It said the 45-year-old had burns covering 75% of his skin.

According to official figures, around 1,400 firefighters were still on duty in Portugal. Efforts were reportedly ongoing to battle a blaze in the central town of Arganil, while other fires were under control or had been extinguished.

Authorities in neighbouring Spain meanwhile breathed a sigh of relief as the heatwave drew to an end and rain arrived in some areas.

The situation in the country is developing positively, Director General for Civil Protection Virginia Barcones said on state television channel RTVE.

But she called for a "final push," noting that 16 forest fires were still active across the country. Since Tuesday, German firefighters have also been deployed in Spain.

Preliminary estimates by the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) on Saturday suggest that more than 4,000 square kilometres have been burned in Spain since the beginning of the year, more than has ever been recorded in an entire year.

In Portugal, an area of almost 2,800 square kilometres has been affected, according to the EFFIS.

urn:contentItem:6GM9-F8H3-RRS4-D099-00000-00Safety warning for firewood collectors as forests set to open up in spring2025-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisSafety warning for firewood collectors as forests set to open up in springMichelle Smith

Spring firewood collection period runs September 1 to November 30

Firewood collectors have been reminded to stick to the rules and prioritise safety as firewood collection areas open for spring on Monday, September 1.

Members of the public can collect firewood for use at home from designated collection areas in state forests and some forest parks, but daily limits and maximum household limits apply.

As spring shapes up, the sound of chainsaws is as common as birds through many bushland areas around Ballarat, particularly on weekends.

Collectors can take two cubic metres per person per day to a maximum of 16 cubic metres per household per financial year.

Outside of the two designated firewood collection periods each year, which run from September 1 to November 30, and March 1 to June 30, it is illegal to collect firewood from public land.

On August 5, Conservation Regulator Forest and Wildlife Officers and police intercepted two people who were allegedly removing firewood from the Glen Park State Forest, north of Ballarat, seizing a trailer loaded with firewood and block splitters.

"Most people do the right thing, collect wood that is already on the ground, take only what they need and stick to limits and rules," said Forest Fire Management Victoria deputy chief fire officer Michael Condon.

He urged people to check the weather and conditions before heading out to collect wood, and take care when using chainsaws and other equipment.

Maps for the spring firewood collection season will be online on September 1.

.Mr Condon urged people to get their wood now, ready for next winter.

"Depending on the species and level of dryness when cut, most wood takes longer than 12 months to dry," he said.

"Ideally people should plan their firewood needs two years in advance."

The following information was released by the New Jersey State Senate, Republicans:

In the wake of massive wildfires raging through New Jersey, Senator Parker Space (R-24) and Senator Latham Tiver (R-8) are intensifying their call for the New Jersey Senate Environment and Energy Committee to convene a hearing with state and local officials to urgently address the states forest management practices. The senators formally requested back in February that a hearing be convened to address forest management and wildfire prevention strategies.

Abnormally high winds and dry conditions have significantly increased the risk of wildfires, said Sen. Space. Our hearts go out to the thousands of residents forced to evacuate impacted areas and our brave fire servicemembers fighting the fire in Ocean County. The string of devasting fires underscores our immediate need to hear from state and local officials so we can reassess and strengthen our forest management strategies and readiness.

A massive wildfire, spanning 11,500 acres, broke out in the Greenwood Forest Wildlife Management area in Ocean County prompting thousands of residents to evacuate amid a state of emergency declaration. Another fire, in Cumberland County, broke out days earlier in the Peaslee Wildlife Management area burning more than 1,300 acres.

Today, the Senate Environment and Energy Committee met to discuss food waste in the Garden State.

While having discussions about food waste is important, we cannot afford to delay action on an issue that is quite literally burning before our eyes, said Sen. Tiver. We need to hear from New Jerseys Forest Fire Service and woodland fire companies so we can help provide the necessary support to better manage our forests before wildfires turn into full-scale disasters. I pray for the families displaced by the Ocean County fire and for the safety of our brave first responders fighting the flames. Its time for the Legislature, the Governor, and the DEP to step up and confront this escalating threat head-on.

urn:contentItem:6GNB-4G03-RTBJ-M1KN-00000-00Climate activists throw paint on the façade of the Sagrada Familia in Barcelona2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisClimate activists throw paint on the façade of the Sagrada Familia in Barcelona


Two climate activists threw paint on the façade of the Sagrada Familia in Barcelona on Sunday in protest against the lack of action on the climate crisis that is fueling forest fires in Spain, according to the organizing group Futuro Vegetal.


In a video posted by Futuro Vegetal on social networks, the two activists can be seen being detained by security guards after spraying red and black paint on a column of the well-known church, shouting "climate justice."
"With this protest, the environmental group denounces the lack of measures of the current government against the climate crisis and the repercussions of this in the fires that have ravaged the peninsula and much of Europe this summer," said Futuro Vegetal in a statement.
The Sagrada Familia, designed by the architect Antoni Gaudí (1852-1926), is one of the main attractions of the tourist city of Barcelona.
Spain has suffered a wave of forest fires in August, which have left four dead and devastated more than 350,000 hectares in the last two weeks, according to the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).
The fires constitute "one of the biggest environmental catastrophes" the country has suffered in recent years, according to the government of socialist Pedro Sánchez, who links their magnitude to climate change.
The situation improved considerably this weekend and the director of Civil Protection and Emergencies, Virginia Barcones, announced on Saturday that the emergency was "coming to an end."
Futuro Vegetal, linked to similar international groups, has staged dozens of similar protests, including one in 2022 in which they glued their hands with rubber to the frames of paintings by Spanish master Francisco de Goya in Madrid's Prado Museum.
They also threw paint at a superyacht in Ibiza that allegedly belonged to Nancy Walton Laurie, the billionaire heiress of U.S. retail giant Walmart, and at a mansion belonging to Lionel Messi located on the same island.

In the last few days, this institution confirmed that a total of six forest fires were extinguished in the districts of Sihuas (Ancash), Iguaín (Ayacucho), Nueva Requena (Ucayali), Mollepata (Cusco), Las Piedras (Madre de Dios) and Cayma (Arequipa). Likewise, another fire was controlled in San Jerónimo (Apurímac), where the flames consumed natural cover without causing damage to the life or health of the population.


Katy Rivera Montalván, Indeci's Risk and Disaster Management specialist, highlighted that the entity, through the National Emergency Operations Center (COEN), maintains a permanent monitoring and coordinates actions with the Regional, Provincial and District Emergency Operations Centers (COER), as well as with local authorities. This ensures an immediate and coordinated response to large-scale emergencies.
In the event of a forest fire, Rivera stressed that the population should not intervene directly if they do not have the appropriate training and equipment.
"The main recommendation is to immediately inform local authorities and first response entities, such as the Volunteer Fire Department (116) and the National Police (105), so that they can activate their protocols of attention," he said.
Likewise, the Indeci representative urged citizens to take preventive measures to reduce the risk of new fires.
"It should be avoided to light fires outdoors near forests or plantations, not to burn vegetable waste or bushes, to completely extinguish bonfires or wood stoves, and not to accumulate flammable materials such as straw or wood, which serve as fuel for fire," he said.
Attention!
- During an emergency, the population should remain calm and follow the instructions of local authorities and response entities, including the Fire Department, the National Police, the Armed Forces, the National Forestry Service (Serfor) and community brigades.
- Indeci, attached to the Ministry of Defense, reminds that responsible and coordinated participation is essential to protect life, ecosystems and reduce the impacts of forest fires in our country.

urn:contentItem:6GN4-SXD3-SD1X-F48N-00000-00Smart sensors in birdhouses to tackle forest fires as part of project2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisSmart sensors in birdhouses to tackle forest fires as part of projectİZMİR

A university in the western province of İzmir has launched an innovative project designed to help prevent forest fires through the installation of smart sensors placed inside birdhouses, as Türkiye has been battling massive blazes in its green zones this summer.

The project, finalized after six months of research, will see sensors deployed across different sections of the forest to instantly measure temperature, humidity, smoke and sudden heat fluctuations.

The data will be transmitted to an artificial intelligence–powered monitoring center, enabling potential fire outbreaks to be detected within seconds.

The initiative was developed by İzmir University of Economics' disaster management center director Prof. Dr. Gökhan Kılıç and mechatronics engineering student Tahsin Can Koçum.

With the system in place, firefighting teams will be able to respond swiftly without losing critical time.

The pilot phase is set to be implemented in İzmir's Balçova district, and thanks to its low cost, the project is expected to provide a scalable model for safeguarding forests.

Each sensor carries a price tag of approximately 1,200 Turkish Liras ($29). It is estimated that just 40 sensors will suffice to monitor the 18-hectare Balçova Forest, meaning round-the-clock surveillance could be maintained for as little as 48,000 liras.

Türkiye has 23.2 million hectares of forested land, including 431,000 hectares in İzmir alone, Kılıç reminded, adding that the technology could serve not only in fire prevention but also in the continuous monitoring of ecosystems.

The sensors will run on solar panels and small batteries, the expert said, adding that a single base station can control up to 10,000 sensors.

"During the day, the solar panel will operate while charging the battery, which then powers the system at night. Even with minimal sunlight, a single sensor can function for 45 days non-stop," Kılıç explained.

Citing rising temperatures, climate change and the surge in wildfires as the key motivations behind the project, Kılıç stressed its urgency.

This summer, Türkiye endured one of the hottest seasons on record, while forest fires — some lasting for days and prompting mass evacuations — swept across large parts of the country.

20 Aug 2025 (Kuwait News Agency) Spanish Official Television reported on Wednesday that wildfires have ravaged 391,600 hectares across Spain since the beginning of the current year, making 2025 the most destructive year in three decades.

It said that according to data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), 350,000 hectares were burned since August 7, the destruction was concentrated particularly in northwestern Spain, where efforts are still underway to contain 22 major wildfires raging in mountainous areas and nature reserves.

The report stated that Spain has received assistance from firefighting teams and amphibious helicopters from Finland, France, Slovakia, Italy, and Germany, pointing out that the fires remain out of control despite the end of the severe heatwave and a noticeable drop in temperatures across the Iberian Peninsula.

It added that the wildfires have not only devastated forests and farmlands but also claimed the lives of four individuals, injured dozens, and forced more than 33,000 people to evacuate their homes.

The fires also disrupted transportation between the capital, Madrid, and the region of Galicia in the northwest, as well as northern Castile and Leon, for over a week, in addition to destroying several mountain villages.

The recent heatwave, which ended last Monday, lasted 16 days, during which temperatures soared to 44 degrees Celsius in several regions, contributing to the rapid spread of the fires.

urn:contentItem:6GRW-S873-RXN7-S242-00000-00Zafranal job call for 150 firefighters for the summer season with a salary of $61,000: requirements and how to register2025-09-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisZafranal job call for 150 firefighters for the summer season with a salary of $61,000: requirements and how to register


With the aim of reinforcing the teams destined to fight forest fires and other high-risk incidents during the summer season, the Ministry of the Interior announced the opening of a call for labor to fill 150 positions of seasonal firefighters destined to the National Fire Department.
The call is made under the framework of Article 131 of Law 17.296 of 2001 and Decree N°301/16 of September 2016, with the objective of establishing an order of priority for these positions to be held from December 1, 2025 to March 31, 2026.


Requirements and conditions for applicants
The Ministry established a series of general requirements for those interested, who must be natural or legal citizens with more than five years of practice, be between 18 and 35 years of age at the close of registration, and have a valid identity card. In addition, they must present a judicial record, a medical certificate attesting to their physical aptitude, and other specific requirements related to previous harvesting experience and possession of a driver's license.
The nominal salary for those selected will be 61,174.71 Uruguayan pesos per month, with additional benefits such as lodging in the detachment, food during the service and access to police health care. Specialized training in forest fire prevention and firefighting will also be offered.
This call contemplates a percentage of vacancies for different social groups. Eight percent of the positions will be reserved for self-identified Afro-descendants, one percent for trans people and two percent for victims of violent crimes.
The selection process
The selection process will consist of several stages, including physical tests and interviews. Among the most important tests are the 1,500-meter foot race, the push-up on the ground, the core test (plancha) and the work capacity test (WCT), which simulates the conditions of physical effort required for Zafra firefighters.
Likewise, the merits of the applicants will be assessed, such as previous experience in firefighting and the possession of driver's license category B or higher. Those applicants who do not pass the physical tests will be eliminated from the process.
Registration and deadlines
Interested applicants must complete the registration form available on the Ministry of the Interior website between September 25 and October 10, 2025. It is essential that applicants keep their e-mail address up to date, as all official communications will be sent by e-mail.
Once the priority list is published, the first 150 applicants will be called for the corresponding medical evaluation. If they do not pass, the next applicants will be summoned according to the order of priority.
For further details, interested parties may access the complete terms and conditions of the call through this link.

urn:contentItem:6GP0-HJP3-S2C2-00Y3-00000-00Forest fires: warning of their enormous impact2025-09-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisForest fires: warning of their enormous impact


Forest fires release a "toxic mix" of pollutants that can deteriorate air quality thousands of kilometers away, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) said yesterday, noting a notable anomaly in the Amazon in 2024.


This UN agency explained that air quality is intimately related to climate change and that both problems must be addressed together.
Fires in the Amazon, Canada and Siberia have provided information on how air quality can be affected on a large scale, the WMO stressed in its fifth annual bulletin on air quality and climate.
"Climate change and air pollution know no national boundaries, as evidenced by intense heat and drought fueling wildfires and degrading air quality for millions of people," said WMO Deputy Secretary-General Ko Barrett.
In examining the interaction between air quality and climate, the WMO highlighted the role of microscopic particles called aerosols in these fires, the formation of winter fog, emissions from shipping and urban pollution.
Particles smaller than 2.5 microns in diameter (PM 2.5) are considered particularly harmful because they can penetrate deep into the lungs or cardiovascular system.
While forest fires in 2024 caused above-average PM 2.5 levels in Canada, Siberia and Central Africa, the largest increase in PM 2.5 was recorded in the Amazon, according to the WMO.
"The largest anomaly occurred in the Amazon basin, as a consequence of unprecedented forest fires in the western Amazon region and drought-fueled fires in northern South America," the WMO said in a statement.
At a press conference, Lorenzo Labrador, WMO scientist, stressed that "the forest fire season tends to be more severe and prolonged each year due to climate change".
He also pointed out that forest fires on one continent ended up causing air pollution on another. "That happened last year and also this year. So you see a degradation of air quality on all continents when weather conditions are favorable," he emphasized.
As an example, he mentioned the case of the fires in Canada that affected Europe. "These fires essentially produced a toxic mixture of components that pollute the air," he summarized.
According to the World Health Organization (WHO), air pollution causes more than 4.5 million premature deaths each year worldwide and carries significant environmental and economic costs.

urn:contentItem:6GP0-HH33-S0GT-42M1-00000-00Civil Defense announces 'total mitigation' of the fire in Ñembi Guasu2025-09-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisCivil Defense announces 'total mitigation' of the fire in Ñembi Guasu


After days of work and operations, the Vice-Ministry of Civil Defense announced this Saturday that the forest fire that affected the Ñembi Guasu de Charagua Iyambae protected area, in the department of Santa Cruz, could be completely mitigated.


As reported, "the total mitigation of the active fire in the protected area" was possible thanks to the coordination between the Government, through the Vice-Ministry of Civil Defense, and the Joint Command of Response to Adverse Events (CCREA), the Mayor's Office of Roboré, the Fundación Amigos de la Naturaleza (FAN), the Dirección de Recursos Naturales de la Gobernación de Santa Cruz (Direna), the organization Naturaleza Tierra y Vida (Nativa), the Unidad de Gestión de Riesgos (UGR) Quebracho and the Gobierno Autónomo Indígena Originario Campesino (GAIOC) de Charagua Iyambae.
There was great concern in the region. In fact, Charagua Iyambae's Legislative Body declared a disaster due to the forest fires affecting the protected area. Support was requested to deal with the emergency, which was already beyond the economic and technical capacities of the area.
ÑEMBI GUASU
The Civil Defense indicated that the intervention began on September 4. The operations included both ground and air work. In this way, the fire that was threatening the life protected in the protected area could be calmed.
Finally, the news of the mitigation came this weekend.
"From September 4 to 6, comprehensive operations were carried out that allowed not only to control the adverse event, but also to minimize the risk of reactivation," said the Vice-Ministry.
"As a result of this joint work, an act of conformity was signed in which the Charagua Iyambae GAIOC and the Risk Management Unit recognize the effectiveness of the actions implemented, highlighting the positive impact of the Bambi Bucket aerial system in the liquidation of the fire," he complemented.
Last month, the Vice-Minister of Civil Defense, Juan Carlos Calvimontes, expressed his concern about the fire in protected areas. Not only has Ñembi Guasu been affected; fires have also entered other protected areas such as Noel Kempff Mercado National Park (Santa Cruz), Tunari (Cochabamba), Sama (Tarija) and others.
The Ministry reaffirmed its permanent monitoring of the country's protected areas. The same happens throughout the national territory, where hot spots, air quality and fire threats are observed every day.

By Chris March

A YOUNG New Forest fire cadet was commended for using her medical skills to help a boy injured in a collision on a scooter.

Mazey Kemish (14), from the Ringwood cadet unit, sprang into action when she saw the incident while travelling home from school in her parents' car.

The youngster had emerged suddenly from between two parked cars, resulting in the crash.

Mazey was said to have remained calm as she used her cadet skills to check the area for safety, keep the boy still because of the high risk of spinal injury and suspected fractured pelvis.

She carefully provided pressure to his leg, which was cut and bleeding, earning her a National Fire Chiefs Council Chairs Award.

The commendation was presented to her by deputy chief fire officer Shantha Dickinson during the Ringwood fire cadet unit's recent pass-out parade.

Hampshire & Isle of Wight Fire and Rescue Service cadets manager Clair Hayward said: "Their intervention when coming across a medical emergency, demonstrates the difference the programme can make to a young person, and how their training can benefit their communities."

The end-of-term pass-out parade celebrated the achievements of all those involved at the unit, including the instructors.

The cadets received their certificates and showcased their skills in front of friends and family.

urn:contentItem:6GKM-BP03-RSJC-S46P-00000-00More than one million hectares burned in the EU by 2025 due to fires2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisMore than one million hectares burned in the EU by 2025 due to fires


So far this year have burned in the European Union 1.023 million hectares in 1,851 fires, four times more than in the same period of 2024, according to data published Tuesday by the European Forest Fire Information System (Effis, for its acronym in English).


Specifically, in the same period last year there were 1,185 fires that burned 222,132 hectares of land in the Twenty-seven, reports Efe.
Between January 1 and August 26 this year have been emitted into the atmosphere 38.37 million tons of carbon dioxide (CO2) as a result of fires, more than three times those generated in the same period of 2024 (11.46 million tons).
Of the total number of hectares burned in the EU, 40% is in Spain, where fire has devastated 413,992 hectares in a total of 268 fires, which already exceeds the annual average of 203 fires recorded between 2006 and 2024, according to EFFIS data.
In Portugal, meanwhile, 270,450 hectares have burned so far this year in 155 fires.
On the other hand, the updated data published Tuesday includes a forecast of fire risk until next Monday, September 1, which includes a "low" risk in France, southern Germany, Italy and most of the Balkans.
With respect to the Iberian Peninsula, details that "conditions will subside" in the north, but the risk will remain "high" or "very high" in much of the territory and even "extreme" or "very extreme" in the southeastern Iberian area.
In the same way, the bulletin contemplates an "extreme" or "very extreme" risk in Belgium, the Netherlands, northern Germany, southern Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary and Romania, as well as "high" in Sicily, Greece and Western Turkey.

urn:contentItem:6GKF-WN83-S6MH-D4CN-00000-00Spain to provide state aid for fire victims as many blazes rage on2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisSpain to provide state aid for fire victims as many blazes rage onMadrid (dpa) -

Citizens affected by the devastating forest and bush fires in Spain in recent weeks are set to receive rapid state financial assistance.

At its first meeting after the summer recess, Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez's Cabinet declared numerous regions disaster zones, the government in Madrid announced on Tuesday.

This designation allows residents to apply for reconstruction aid under the Civil Protection Act.

The support is intended not only for victims of the 113 forest fires that have swept across the country this summer, particularly since early August, but also for those hit by five severe storms that caused flooding, including flash floods.

Although the situation has eased since the weekend, many fires are still burning. Currently, 15 major blazes are active, Interior Minister Fernando Grande-Marlaska told reporters.

Three fires in the provinces of Zamora, León, and Lugo in north-western Spain are considered especially serious. Officials have described the wildfires as the most severe in decades.

Northern and western Spain have been particularly hard hit since August 5 during an unusually long heatwave. No official damage assessment is available.

According to the latest estimate by the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), more than 4,100 square kilometres of land has been destroyed in Spain since the beginning of the year.

Since the beginning of August, about 3,500 square kilometres has burnt.

Neighbouring Portugal experienced fierce fires in August.

According to EFFIS, some 2,700 square kilometres of land has been destroyed, mostly in sparsely populated areas. Both Spain and Portugal reported four fatalities each. As in Spain, numerous fires were still burning in Portugal on Tuesday.

Fines for traffic infractions have been reduced during nighttime operations carried out on Fridays and Saturdays. These controls are carried out in the main avenues of Portoviejo, such as Manabí, to prevent people from consuming alcoholic beverages on public roads.


Patricio Puga, coordinator of Security and Territorial Control of the municipality, reported that they have held discussions with the owners of the bars to support this work, so that people do not consume alcoholic beverages on public roads. In fact, he emphasized that Portovial and National Police personnel are in charge of sanctioning vehicle owners who commit any infraction.
Several institutions participate in the operations
Personnel from Portovial, National Police, Municipal Control, Territorial Control, Municipal Police Station and Armed Forces participate in these operations. The controls include document revision, noise control, bad parking and improper presence on public roads.
Ulbio Molineros, director of Operational Control of Portovial, informed that from an average of 60 fines issued three months ago when they started these operations, they have been reduced by 50%."Since we started the controls, they have dropped quite a lot," he said.
The operations are carried out from 23h00 on Friday and culminate after 01h00 on Saturday. The same schedule is from Saturday to Sunday. Molineros emphasized that the fines are for having films in vehicles, bad parking and environmental pollution. That is, those who take out their speakers to drink on public roads.
They ask for more controls in the ex-airport lands.
Those who live in the Los Mangos neighborhood request that the controls be extended to the interior of the land. Gustavo Triviño, inhabitant of the sector, assured that people frequently come to drink alcohol and consume prohibited substances, mainly at night.
In fact, last weekend there was a forest fire in the vacant lots of this neighborhood, where people come to dump garbage. "This is a mess and there is no control," commented Triviño, who said that motorcyclists also occasionally arrive to carry out clandestine races.
Patricio Puga, indicated that they have already received complaints that people come to drink in the vacant lots adjacent to the former airport. In fact, this weekend they built a ditch so that vehicles cannot enter.
He announced that the owners of the land will be notified so that they clean their land and make the respective enclosure. However, he assured that they have not received any complaints about clandestine races. "When there have been races it is because they have been with permits", he pointed out.

urn:contentItem:6GKM-BNY3-RSC5-G3K5-00000-00Santa Cruz Governor's Office declares orange alert for forest fires2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisSanta Cruz Governor's Office declares orange alert for forest fires


The Governor's Office of Santa Cruz has declared an orange alert for forest fires this Tuesday, August 26, 2025. This decision was taken after the report of 63 hot spots and three active fires in the municipalities of San Ignacio de Velasco, San Matías and El Carmen Rivero Torrez.


The head of the Directorate of Natural Resources (Direna) of the Government, Paulo Viruez, announced at a press conference that the orange alert is issued from the center of the Early Warning System of Forest Fires (Satif). This measure is based on the provisions of Law 602 of Risk Management, considering several factors that require immediate attention.
Most affected municipalities
So far this year, the municipalities that have had the most recurrent fires are San José, Porongo, San Ignacio, San Matías and El Carmen Rivero Torrez. In view of this worrying situation, Viruez urged the Autonomous Municipal Governments to activate communication and dissemination mechanisms to inform the populations that could be affected by potential risks.
Emergency Protocols
He also requested that the necessary protocols be activated in the event of disasters and emergencies in their regions. The municipalities should initially and in progress operate the personnel, logistics and financial resources that are necessary for the attention of forest fire emergencies that could occur, following the regular established procedures.
Importance of prevention
Viruez emphasized that "prevention is the effective tool to protect our communities, natural resources and the well-being of everyone in the department". This statement highlights the importance of taking proactive measures to mitigate the impact of wildfires in the region.

The Secretary of the Environment of Coahuila, headed by Susana Estens de la Garza, will implement a digital platform to track the traceability of waste, from its generation to its final destination. This initiative seeks to combat the proliferation of clandestine dumps, such as the recent case of batteries and batteries found in Ramos Arizpe.

The secretary emphasized that this tool will allow greater oversight over waste generators and transporters. "What we are doing is precisely through the application of the law, but supported by a digital platform," explained the official. The objective is to prevent "these mysterious dumps".
In relation to the case of Ramos Arizpe, the official said that the platform will make it possible to trace how these batteries arrived and who generated them, since the volume found does not correspond to domestic waste. The reward offered by the mayor of Ramos Arizpe was key to obtain information.
Estens de la Garza emphasized that the law establishes that the generator is responsible for his waste until its final destination. "So, it is that traceability that is what we have to do in a timely manner and through this platform and through artificial intelligence, from generator, the transporter and the destination," he detailed.
The head of the agency also referred to the forest fire season, assuring that, despite the punctual incidents, the numbers are positive compared to other years. "We are with very good numbers and we hope that we continue like this," she said.
The Secretary of Environment thanked the support of citizens, who have been instrumental in the rapid reporting of fires. "This report that we have from the citizens that let's see, here is smoke, and then in a super fast way we acted through the brigades," she said.
Regarding urban growth in protected areas, such as the Sierra de Zapalinamé, the secretary described it as a "great challenge". She acknowledged that this phenomenon is not exclusive to Saltillo, but is also observed in other cities such as Monterrey.
Finally, the official reaffirmed the agency's commitment to continue acting in response to these problems. "We will have to continue looking for ways to minimize and control it in the case of a protected natural area. Definitely, that is why the guidelines and management plans are established," she said.

urn:contentItem:6GMX-5BS3-RSC2-P0VX-00000-00Türkiye's summer heat to linger until October, expert says2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisTürkiye's summer heat to linger until October, expert saysISTANBUL

Temperatures across Türkiye are expected to dip slightly in the week of Sept. 1, yet autumn will hold off for some time as summer heat is forecast to persist through October, according to a meteorologist.

"Starting Monday [Sept. 1], temperatures nationwide, including Istanbul, will decrease by 1–2 degrees. However, they will not fall below seasonal averages. In Istanbul, temperatures will hover around 32 degrees Celsius," prominent meteorologist Orhan Şen said.

"Summer will last until October, and even into mid-October, we may experience a warm, summer-like climate," he added.

Şen also warned that Türkiye, already grappling with drought, will not see the rainfall it desperately needs in the near term.

"Precipitation has declined by 74 percent. We are living through the hottest and driest period in the past 65 years. Agricultural drought is now imminent. Farmers will not be able to plant because the soil has not retained moisture," he said.

This year, Türkiye has endured one of the driest summers on record. In its third-largest city, the western province of İzmir, authorities began introducing controlled water cuts last month due to plummeting reservoir levels.

At the same time, the country has been battling major wildfires. As of Sept. 1, a forest fire in the western province of Denizli continued into its fourth day, forcing the precautionary evacuation of two neighborhoods.

Climate change, with its rising temperatures and reduced rainfall, intensified massive wildfires in Türkiye, Greece and Cyprus this summer, according to a study published last week.

The study by World Weather Attribution said the fires that killed 20 people, forced 80,000 to evacuate and burned more than 1 million hectares (2.47 million acres) were 22 percent more intense in 2025, Europe's worst recorded year of wildfires.

Hundreds of wildfires that broke out in the eastern Mediterranean in June and July were driven by temperatures above 40 degrees Celsius (about 104 Fahrenheit), extremely dry conditions and strong winds.

WWA, a group of researchers that examines whether and to what extent extreme weather events are linked to climate change, called its findings "concerning."

More than 120 representatives of 16 native communities of Atalaya, Ucayali, participated in training workshops to strengthen the monitoring and sustainable management of their communal forests. The initiative was organized by the Ministry of Environment's Forestry Program in coordination with state institutions, indigenous organizations and regional partners.


The workshops were aimed at the custodians of the Community Forest Surveillance and Control Committees of Ucayali - Atalaya, who play a key role as environmental defenders.
The custodians received training on forestry legislation, environmental crimes, forest fire management, social and environmental safeguards, good forest harvesting practices, compensation mechanisms for fines and integrity in forest management.
Invited institutions such as the Ministry of Justice and Human Rights, SERFOR, OSINFOR, SOFFSA of the Regional Government of Ucayali, the Specialized Environmental Prosecutor's Office, the National Association of Contract Executors for the Administration of Communal Reserves (ANECAP) and the Contract Executor for the Administration of the El Sira Communal Reserve (ECOSIRA) participated in this effort.
One of the educational tools used was the "Forestry Backpack: Institutionalism and the Fight against Corruption", developed and delivered by OSINFOR and Proética.

urn:contentItem:6GNS-2D53-RRWT-K121-00000-00Forest fires deteriorate air quality kilometers away, warns UN2025-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisForest fires deteriorate air quality kilometers away, warns UN


Forest fires release a "toxic mixture" of pollutants that can deteriorate air quality thousands of kilometers away, the WMO (World Meteorological Organization) said on Friday (5).


The United Nations agency stressed that air quality is closely related to climate change and that the two problems must be tackled together.
In the fifth edition of the annual report on air pollution and climate, experts analyzed how air quality could be affected on a large scale from the major fires in the Amazon, Canada and Siberia in 2024.
"Climate change and air pollution know no national borders, as demonstrated by the intense heat and drought that fuel forest fires and degrade air quality for millions of people," said WMO Assistant Secretary-General Ko Barrett.
At a press conference, WMO scientist Lorenzo Labrador pointed out that the forest fire season tends to be more severe and prolonged every year due to climate change.
He also pointed out that forest fires on one continent have ended up causing air pollution on another. "This happened last year and this year too. So we see a deterioration in air quality on all continents when the weather conditions are favorable," he emphasized.
As an example, Labrador mentioned the case of the fires in Canada, which ended up affecting Europe. "These fires essentially produced a toxic mixture of components that pollute the air," he summarized.
When examining the interaction between air quality and climate, the WMO highlights the role of aerosols (microscopic, floating particles) in fires, in the formation of winter fog, in shipping emissions and in urban pollution.
Particles with a diameter of less than 2.5 micrometers (PM 2.5) are considered particularly harmful because they can penetrate deep into the lungs or cardiovascular system.
Although the forest fires of 2024 caused higher than average levels of PM 2.5 in Canada, Siberia and Central Africa, the largest increase in PM 2.5 was recorded in the Amazon rainforest.
"The largest anomaly occurred in the Amazon basin, as a result of the unprecedented forest fires recorded in the western Amazon region and the drought-fueled fires that have punished northern South America," the WMO said in a statement.
According to the World Health Organization (WHO), air pollution causes more than 4.5 million premature deaths each year worldwide and entails significant environmental and economic costs.

urn:contentItem:6H0B-C3F3-RRP9-44B0-00000-00HOW AI CAN HELP FUND RESILIENCE, NOT DISASTERS2025-10-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisHOW AI CAN HELP FUND RESILIENCE, NOT DISASTERSStates News ServiceGENEVA, Switzerland

The following information was released by United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction (UNDRR):

In 2024, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) recorded 617extreme weather events based on reports from countries worldwide. Of those, 152were classified as unprecedented and 297as unusual.

According to WMO's State of the Global Climate report, these disasters displaced more than 824,000people, injured 1.1million, and caused 1,700fatalities.

Although the numbers are troubling, they do not capture the full spectrum of impacts and consequences as global climate change takes hold. Intensifying disasters also, for example, entail a financial burden.

This hinders development in the most vulnerable and often most exposed regions and, in turn, can push climate change mitigation and adaptation measures further out of reach.

Compounding the cost of climate change adaptation are crucially overlooked factors in global and regional finance, such as on the role of ecosystems like wetlands and forests in the provision of essential services.

A recent study on European banks found that ecosystem degradation and biodiversity loss affect financial systems significantly and must be included and integrated into risk assessments.

At the 2025 Pan-European Summit on Climate Resilience, leaders and experts called for urgent, just, and science-based action to strengthen resilience and develop strategies grounded in local communities and natural systems, noting Europe's position at the forefront of the pathway to a resilient future.

Applying AI to global datasets

This year's International Day for Disaster Risk Reduction calls on governments and institutions to "Fund Resilience, Not Disasters." That means financial decisions and assessments must better account for the interplay of climate risks, land degradation and biodiversity loss.

Artificial intelligence (AI) through its ability to quickly ingest, process, and find patterns within vast, complex datasets can help flag key factors across and within financial, economic, social, and natural systems.

Machine learning is already being applied to identify hidden drivers of heatwaves and improve the detection and predictability of such extremes. Similarly, AI techniques have increased the predictability of cyclones in the tropics and other regions.

Other studies are using machine learning to identify areas where agriculture requires transformative adaption.

For land degradation, AlphaEarth Foundations is fusing satellite-based Earth observation and climate data to develop detailed global maps of land degradation, deforestation, soil health, and other variables.

Biodiversity experts have used machine learning to model future forest fire susceptibility in monoculture regions and to highlight benefits of mixed forests.

Unpacking complex risks

In terms of financing, AI can help shift the focus from urgent disaster relief to long-term investments in climate resilience. It can do so by tackling the immense complexity of the climate crisis.

Climate threats often consist of multi-hazard events with cascading financial and social effects. AI excels in processing the vast, complex data from environmental, climate, and financial systems. From there, it can create robust, systemic risk models that human analysts could never manage at scale.

Optimizing cash flows

Another way AI can contribute is by optimizing cash flows. Specifically, it can transfer complex climate-biodiversity-land (CBL) data into decision-ready finance metrics, making CBL risk measurable, priceable, and bankable.

For private investors, AI provides strong analytics on ways to prevent losses and, by showing how to stabilize cash flows, can make nature-based solutions more attractive.

By balancing financial returns and environmental benefits, AI lets private investors go from reactive to proactive.

For public resources, AI can determine where funds would work best to de-risk private investments in the context of blended finance strategies. This would create a chance to boost climate and nature resilience and reduce systemic risks.

Making AI accessible and explainable

To fully achieve AI's potential for sustainable resilience, some critical conditions must be met.

Countries and organizations need shared and widespread data and computational infrastructures, with equitable access to standardized, high-quality data enabling effective results with AI.

Still, people may rightly not accept AI-based decisions with direct social consequences.

To foster trust, AI models need to explain themselves.

Explainable AI (xAI) ensures that models, often trained on decades of expert knowledge, also reveal clearly why they make a certain prediction.

In the case of AI-driven investment and funding decisions, this is key for grounding financial outputs in verifiable physical and expert principles. Thus, AI can help guide capital toward proactive, verifiable resilience projects.

Pulling together

Our call for action on this International Day for Disaster Risk Reduction is clear: governments and businesses must prioritise resilience in funding decisions.

This can be aided by integrating AI into long-term policy and financial frameworks for climate resilience.

Here, international coordination will be crucial for success.

Interdisciplinary and international standardization efforts, like the Global Initiative on Resilience to Natural Hazards through AI Solutions and its new Working Group on AI for Climate Applications, can provide important insights and guidelines.

Together, we must determine how AI can best support informed financial decisions related to the climate and nature crisis.

TheGlobal Initiative on Resilience to Natural Hazards through AI Solutionsis co-led by various UN agencies: the International Telecommunication Union (ITU), the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), the Universal Postal Union (UPU), the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), and the UN Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).

The Working Group on AI for Climate Applications is a collaborative expert group within the Global Initiative that aims to harness AI for practical climate change mitigation and adaptation, particularly addressing the needs of developing countries, least developed countries, and small island developing states.

urn:contentItem:6GNS-2DH3-RRPK-60F6-00000-00The latest Copernicus update brings the number of hectares burned in August to 336,345 hectares, 7% less than expected.2025-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisThe latest Copernicus update brings the number of hectares burned in August to 336,345 hectares, 7% less than expected.


Forest fires have burned a total of 336,345 hectares across Spain during August, according to data from the European Commission's European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) from Copernicus as of August 31.


This figure is 7 percent lower than the latest data provided by Copernicus, which estimated that between August 1 and 21 had burned 362,473 hectares, because the satellite information is being adjusted and improving its resolution.
This was announced this Friday by the third vice-president and minister for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge, Sara Aagesen, during her appearance in the Commission of Ecological Transition in the Congress of Deputies.
The main changes affect especially those autonomous communities that on August 21, the last information officially supplied by the Ministry, still had active forest fires.
By autonomous community, the largest area affected is in Galicia, with 143,628 hectares, 43%; Castilla y León, 141,264 hectares, 42%; Extremadura, 41,525 hectares, 12%. These three communities account for 97% of the area affected in August. The remaining 10,000 hectares are distributed in the rest of the autonomous communities that have had some fire episode during August.
Of this figure, 325,000 hectares correspond to large forest fires, fires of more than 500 hectares, which means that 97% of the area affected was precisely due to these large forest fires. The forested area affected is 128,350 hectares, almost 40% of the area affected by the fires.
In the case of the Natura 2000 Network, the area burned by forest fires amounted to 146,190 hectares, i.e. 43% of the area burned.
Also affected have been critical areas for the survival of more than 350 species in danger of extinction, vulnerable or in some protection regime according to the LESPRE list, species such as the urugallo, species such as the brown bear, the lynx or the black stork.
"We are facing a loss that goes beyond the immediate. Fires have an amplifying effect on another of the great crises we suffer, which is the crisis of biodiversity, an essential value. A value that is also suffering with crudeness those protected areas, environmental, those biosphere reserves," lamented Aagesen.

urn:contentItem:6G00-K603-RS5J-63RM-00000-00Studies from Nipissing University Reveal New Findings on Forestry (Oxygen isotope values of charred tree bark as an indicator of forest fire severity)2025-06-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisLIFE SCIENCES - FORESTRYStudies from Nipissing University Reveal New Findings on Forestry (Oxygen isotope values of charred tree bark as an indicator of forest fire severity)


2025 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Life Science Daily -- Investigators publish new report on forestry. According to news reporting out of North Bay, Canada, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "The objective of this study was to determine if oxygen isotope values of charred tree bark could be used to reconstruct fire severity."


The news editors obtained a quote from the research from Nipissing University: "The study was completed north of River Valley, Ontario, Canada, where a wildfire burned approximately 2500 hectares of white pine (Pinus strobus L.) forest in 2018. We established a network of field plots, collected charred bark samples from standing white pine stems, and estimated burn severity based on a standard field assessment protocol known as the Composite Burn Index (CBI). We also analyzed pre- and post-fire Sentinel-2 imagery of the burn area to compute various Normalized Burn Ratio (NBR)-based change detection algorithms, which are known to produce reliable predictions of CBI. We developed simple linear regression models to predict CBI using either the d18O values of charred bark or versions of the NBR. Models developed from the d18O values of charred bark revealed a significant negative relationship between CBI and plot-level d18O, with the strongest relationship being with maximum d18O (r2 = 0.179, RMSE = 0.565). There were significant positive relationships between all NBR indices and CBI, with better fit statistics than the d18O models."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The results demonstrate that d18O can be used as a predictor of fire severity; however, the scale of measurement of fire severity is finer (tree-level) than the plot-level CBI and NBR indices. The advantage of using the d18O method is that it can be used to reconstruct fire severity when satellite or field data are unavailable."
For more information on this research see: Oxygen isotope values of charred tree bark as an indicator of forest fire severity. Trees, Forests and People, 2025,20():100786. The publisher for Trees, Forests and People is Elsevier.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tfp.2025.100786.

urn:contentItem:6GNS-2DH3-RRHB-X49B-00000-00UN warns that wildfires degrade global air quality2025-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisUN warns that wildfires degrade global air quality


Forest firesrelease a "toxic mix" of pollutants that can deteriorate air quality thousands of kilometers away, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) said Friday, noting a notable anomaly in the Amazon in 2024.
This UN agency explained that air quality is intimately related to climate change and that both problems must be addressed together.


Fires in the Amazon, Canada and Siberia have provided information on how air quality can be affected on a large scale, the WMO stressed in its fifth annual bulletin on air quality and climate.
Climate change and air pollution know no national boundaries, as evidenced by intense heat and drought fueling wildfires and degrading air quality for millions of people," said WMO Deputy Secretary-General Ko Barrett.
In examining the interaction between air quality and climate, the WMO highlighted the role of microscopic particles called aerosols in these fires, the formation of winter fog, emissions from shipping and urban pollution.
Particles smaller than 2.5 microns in diameter (PM 2.5) are considered particularly harmful because they can penetrate deep into the lungs or cardiovascular system.
While forest fires in 2024 caused above-average PM 2.5 levels in Canada, Siberia and Central Africa, the largest increase in PM 2.5 was recorded in the Amazon, according to the WMO.
The largest anomaly occurred in the Amazon basin as a result of unprecedented forest fires in the western Amazon region and drought-fueled fires in northern South America," the WMO said in a statement.
At a press conference, Lorenzo Labrador, WMO scientist, stressed that "the forest fire season tends to be more severe and prolonged each year due toclimate change".
He also pointed out that forest fires on one continent ended up causing air pollution on another. "That happened last year and also this year. So you see a degradation of air quality on all continents when weather conditions are favorable," he emphasized.
As an example, he mentioned the case of the fires in Canada that affected Europe.
These fires essentially produced a toxic mixture of components that pollute the air," he summarized.
According to the World Health Organization (WHO), air pollution causes more than 4.5 million premature deaths each year around the world and carries significant environmental and economic costs.
