urn:contentItem:6GNS-2DH3-RRPK-60KH-00000-00Marta Corella, forestry engineer: "A forest that doesn't smell of wood will smell of smoke.2025-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisMarta Corella, forestry engineer: "A forest that doesn't smell of wood will smell of smoke.


Forestry experts have met this Thursday at the Press Association of Madrid (APM), in a forum organized by the Pau Costa Foundation, to put on the table seven "key" work axes to address the fires in Spain, including the management of forests, territorial planning, the creation of living rural communities, take advantage of the use and ecology of fire, influence education and training, improve the response capacity and analyze future scenarios.


Seven axes that had already been presented in 2023 in a forum organized by the Pau Costa Foundation and the forest fire community. "Unfortunately, two years later, we can say that little or nothing of what was agreed upon has been carried out," said Luis Berbiela, trustee of the Pau Costa Foundation.
Berbiela lamented a "lack of political will" and pointed out that "the challenge of forest fires is a national challenge", in which these axes "should serve as a road map" beyond "political dissidence".
In view of the "more than 400,000 hectares burned", the experts have insisted, especially, on the importance of managing forests and their "immense" biomass to prevent fires. "A forest that does not smell of wood will smell of smoke," said Marta Corella, vice-dean of the Association of Forestry and Environmental Engineering.
Arantza Pérez, vice-dean of the Official College of Forestry Engineers, also stressed that the forestry sector must be a "pillar, strong and attractive sector on which everything else is built".
She criticized that "only 0.008% of the national GDP" is destined to "manage, prevent and extinguish" and insisted that management facilitates prevention, minimizes the "fuel load" available to burn and becomes the "perfect equation" to "regulate the cycle of fire" or to deal with "rural employment".
Territorial planning
Territorial planning is also key to prevent fires, according to Juan Picos, professor of Forestry Engineering at the University of Vigo. "It is the only thing that allows us to choose the plot on which we play, and we have to work with a certain criterion," he explained.
He stressed the need to establish "synergies between administrations" to defend the "great magnitude" of the fires since "resources are and will always be scarce" and "planning allows us to allocate them where they are optimal".
Picos stresses that territorial planning will facilitate "making prevention where it should be done, not where it can be done" so that "every million euros" is executed "where it will work best".
Living rural communities
Marta Corella also stressed the importance of "generating more resilient forests" and paying attention to rural communities "immensely rich in heritage" that "are living in economic destitution".
She has lamented an "unfair distribution" of state taxes in the face of territories with "few inhabitants" that "cannot generate job opportunities for their people". "Despite having 56% of its territory at the service of society, these communities do not compute when distributing these taxes," he added.
Corella denounces a society that is "very short-sighted and unaware" of the "history" of its forests and maintains that the key is to have an impact on "the resources generated by the forest". "We have to make a big decision, if we want forests or we want to cry it when we go through them on carbon," he adds.
Fire use and ecology
Also "learning from the uses of fire" is "key" to influence its prevention, according to Luis Berbiela, resorting to "prescribed burns" or "grazed burns" to increase the "chances of extinction".
He has stressed that "recovering the culture of controlled fire is vital in the country" with "laws that support this management". "We have to know that we are going to live with fire, but it is better to live with a controlled and programmed fire than with fires that overwhelm us", he added.
Education and training
In the words of Ferran Dalmau, forestry engineer and director of Medi XXI GSA, another key is to focus on "training and education" to create "more prepared communities" that "look more" for their ecosystems.
Dalmau calls on the educational community to "foster consensus in times of polarization" because "a falling tree makes more noise than a growing forest" and lamented a society that "lacks situational awareness". "We have to start earning the surname Sapiens," he has lamented.
Response capacity
To improve the capacity to respond to the flames, Juan Caamaño, head of the Training and Operations area of the Pau Costa Foundation, stressed the need to "create" a "Research Center on the behavior of fire" to acquire "more knowledge" to "reduce uncertainty".
Likewise, he insisted on "increasing cooperation" between autonomous communities through an "organism or entity" that facilitates "coordination between them" and creating a "certification system" that influences "this collaboration capacity".
Future scenarios
According to Joaquín Ramírez, it is now necessary to assume "fires that have burned with extreme intensity" and that will affect "the clogging of reservoirs", "floods" and territories that have already been "punished in the human sphere". "What is coming is going to be much worse than what we have if we do not address it as a society," he lamented.
In addition, another of the keys is "adapting to climate change", in the words of Mónica Parrilla, forestry engineer and head of forest fire campaigns at GreenpeaceSpain, although "climate change does not cause", but rather "aggravates the dangerous situations of fires".
She points out that weather conditions have had an impact on the current reality of "abandonment of the countryside" which has meant "more fuel", a situation that "will continue to increase" if "no action is taken".

The remaining 10,000 hectares are distributed in the rest of the autonomous communities that have had some fire episode during August.
Of this figure, 325,000 hectares correspond to large forest fires, fires of more than 500 hectares, which means that 97% of the area affected was precisely due to these large forest fires. The forested area affected is 128,350 hectares, almost 40% of the area affected by the fires.
In the case of the Natura 2000 Network, the area burned by forest fires amounted to 146,190 hectares, i.e. 43% of the area burned.
Also affected have been critical areas for the survival of more than 350 species in danger of extinction, vulnerable or in some protection regime according to the LESPRE list, species such as the urugallo, species such as the brown bear, the lynx or the black stork.
"We are facing a loss that goes beyond the immediate. Fires have an amplifying effect on another of the great crises we suffer, which is the crisis of biodiversity, an essential value. A value that is also suffering harshly those protected areas, environmental, these biosphere reserves," lamented Aagesen.

Vox has filed this Monday before theSupreme Courta complaint against the president, Pedro Sánchez, the ministers of Interior and Defense, Fernando Grande-Marlaska and Margarita Robles, and the 'popular' presidents of Castilla y León, Andalusia, Extremadura and Galicia for the alleged commission of the crimes of reckless homicide, forest fire, against the rights of workers and prevarication in the response to forest fires.


The complaint also includes the Minister for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge, Sara Aagesen the director of Civil Protection and Emergencies, Virgina Barcones the president of Asturias, the socialist Adrián Barbón, and the regional councilors and general directors, according to the document.
Failure of the autonomic system
The formation led by Santiago Abascal puts the focus on the"very serious negligence" of the state and regional authorities in the phases related to firefighting: forecasting, fighting active fires and subsequent phase."This situation could have been avoided or mitigated to a great extent if the political leaders, with competences in environment and fire prevention had acted executing all the measures that could foresee and avoid these fires," Vox points out.
In addition, in the letter, Vox considers that not having declared the emergency situation as of national interest has constituted "a very serious act of imprudence that has originated and / or aggravated the risks and damages" of the crimes that the formation blames the defendants, especially in the phase of first response to the emergency, "the most critical".
"Whoever falls"
In this context, Vox believes that the "disastrous situation" suffered with the fires, which have devastated nearly 400,000 hectares, derives from "the confluence of competences of various administrations derived from the state configuration and the autonomic, and even municipal competences".
"The tangle of regulatory texts and the confluence of coordinators in the management of these emergency risks have evidenced not only the real and effective impossibility of fulfilling the purpose for which they were dictated, but a twisted use and political and partisan interest have worsened an emergency situation leading to a catastrophic situation as it has left us," regrets Vox, which calls the management of "criminal".
The national spokesman of Vox, José Antonio Fúster, has announced the presentation of the"macroquerella" in a press conference during this day, pointing out that the party will go "all out" and"whoever falls", including the Popular Party.

urn:contentItem:6GKD-DGK3-RS8V-R0H5-00000-00Bolivia seeks access to $US 2,000 million per year from the "Amazon Forever" fund2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisBolivia seeks access to $US 2,000 million per year from the "Amazon Forever" fund


The Government has stated that it is working to comply with the necessary requirements to access up to US$ 2 billion per year from the Amazon Forever international financial program. This program is promoted by the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB).


The Minister of Environment and Water, Alvaro Ruiz, explained on August 25 that one of the most important criteria to benefit from this mechanism is to maintain a deforestation rate of less than 0.3% per year. "It is a challenge that implies strengthening reforestation plans and forest fire control," he emphasized.
Presentation of the fund
This fund was presented during the V Meeting of Presidents of the States Parties to the Amazon Cooperation Treaty (ACT), held in Colombia, where President Luis Arce participated. The objective of this program is to raise up to US$125 billion to ensure the sustainable development and conservation of the Amazon.
Benefits for indigenous peoples
According to the established rules, 20% of the resources must go directly to Amazonian indigenous peoples, regardless of whether the channeling of these funds is public or private.
Conservation actions
Ruiz also indicated that Bolivia is already carrying out environmental prevention and restoration actions as part of its conservation strategy. Access to this funding will allow Bolivia to expand forest management and natural area protection projects and strengthen the institutions involved.
National State of Emergency
Currently, the departments most affected by forest fires are Beni and Santa Cruz. In view of this situation, the Government has declared a national state of emergency, which allows for the allocation of additional resources for immediate attention to these fires.

A fourth person died Saturday as Portugal continues to battle wildfires that began in early August.

The death toll rose after a 45-year-old firefighter, who was seriously injured while battling flames in Sabugal on Tuesday, died early Saturday morning, broadcaster RTP reported.

The country continues to battle wildfires across multiple regions, with the town of Arganil in central Portugal receiving the most attention from civil protection, supported by the deployment of 1,470 personnel.

The Portuguese Institute of the Sea and Atmosphere (IPMA) maintained the fire risk as "maximum," "very high," or "high" in many municipalities in the northern and central interior.

Two suspects are said to be arrested on suspicion of starting a forest fire that started Aug. 18 in the town of Lousa.

Spain sees improvement in wildfire situation

Meanwhile, Spain, which has been battling wildfires since early August, started to see improvements in its ongoing fire situation, according to broadcaster RTVE.

Virginia Barcones, director general of civil protection, said the number of active level 2 fires has dropped to 13 across the regions of Castile and Leon, Galicia, and Asturias.

The main concern remains the Iguena fire in Leon, where difficult terrain is limiting access to the most dangerous northern front.

A fire in Galicia, once considered the worst in the region's history, has also been stabilized after burning over 30,000 hectares (74,132 acres).

The total area burned in Spain so far this year has exceeded 400,000 hectares (988,420 acres), citing the latest estimates from the European Copernicus service.

urn:contentItem:6GN9-MC23-RYTH-N1MD-00000-00Spain's sees worst wildfire season since 1994 with 382,000 hectares burned so far in 20252025-08-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisSpain's sees worst wildfire season since 1994 with 382,000 hectares burned so far in 2025

The European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) calculate that 380,000 hectares have burned in Spain so far this year, while the fight against the flames continues.

All the ingredients came together to create the perfect storm: a particularly dry spring in western Spain, followed by a heatwave that wiped out any remaining moisture in dense, dry ground-level vegetation. Add to that a lack of forest management and limited resources, something fire brigades across the affected autonomous communities have repeatedly warned about.

This combination has resulted in the most severe wave of summer wildfires Spain has seen since 1994, when 437,602 hectares burned, according to data from the Ministry of the Environment.

The European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), part of the EU’s Copernicus programme, estimates that 382,607 hectares have burned in Spain this year across 228 fires, a figure that continues to rise as fires rage across Galicia, Asturias, Castilla y León, and Extremadura. These regions, with the exception of Extremadura, are among the oldest and most depopulated in the country.

Depopulation also impacts forest upkeep. Traditional practices like extensive livestock grazing, which once naturally cleaned up the forest during the winter and spring, have largely disappeared.

Of the 10 most destructive wildfires this century in Spain, five have occurred in just the last 15 days of August this year: A Rúa in Orense (44,424 hectares), Uña de Quintana in Zamora (40,781), Benuza in León (32,596), Manzaneda (28,485) and Oímbra (28,485), also in the region of Orense.

What makes this wave of fires especially concerning is that, while the total number of large wildfires (those over 500 hectares) isn't unusually high, they are spreading much more easily due to weather conditions. In 2025, Spain has so far had 52 large fires and we only have to go back to 2022 to exceed that figure.

The complaint, which has been accessed, accuses those responsible for various crimes and asks the highest levels to analyze the degree of involvement of each of the defendants. The formation led by Santiago Abascal attributes to the mentioned persons the commission of the crimes of reckless homicide, forest fire, and prevarication. Outside the political leaders, there is the socialist militant and general director of Civil Protection and Emergencies, Virginia Barcones.
Within the crimes mentioned, the formation that instructs Santiago Abascal puts the focus on the "negligence" of the state and autonomic responsible in all phases to fight fires." This situation could have been avoided if the political leaders with powers in environment had executed all the measures that could foresee and avoid these fires", denounces the formation.
For Vox, having avoided resorting to the national emergency has been a "very serious mistake" that has increased the burned hectares and material losses caused by the flames in Galicia, Extremadura and Castilla y León. They point out that the lack of clarity in the competences of the administrations has caused a "disastrous situation". From the formation advocate to reduce the state bureaucracy and denounce that the texts have been used" in a twisted and partisan way".
Santiago Abascal's and Vox's lawsuits intensify
In the same way that a "macro lawsuit" has been filed this morning, the formation has increased its activity in the courts with the beginning of the new political course. Amongst the dispatches from the Marine Captaincy of Santa Cruz de Tenerife, there is the lawsuit filed against the Open Arms, to inspect the legality of their actions in Spain. On the way are new legal texts to close the centers for minors in Spain.
As a response, before Abascal's words, the partners of the Government, have also resorted to the Canary Prosecutor's Office and have sued the president of the formation for calling to "sink the slave ship" of the Open Arms. 2025 SEP 01 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- A new study on ecology is now available. According to news reporting out of the University of Connecticut by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Forest fires play an important role in shaping ecosystems but increasingly threaten biodiversity and carbon dynamics."


Financial supporters for this research include National Science Foundation Hdr Award; China Scholarship Council.
Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from University of Connecticut: "Advancements in remote sensing and machine learning have facilitated the monitoring and prediction of burn severity, yet a comprehensive global assessment of severity trends and their climatic drivers remain limited. In this study, we analyzed burn severity trends across global ecoregions from 2003 to 2023 using a newly developed 30-m resolution Global Burn Severity Dataset. We observed significant increases in forest fire burn severity in tropical and subtropical regions, while boreal zones exhibited declines. For ecoregions showing significant trends, we developed predictive models using XGBoost and 14 climate variables from the TerraClimate dataset to identify key drivers. Our analysis highlighted the influence of regional climate variables on wildfire dynamics."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "These findings enhance our understanding of wildfire-climate interactions and support management strategies aimed at mitigating wildfire impacts on biodiversity and carbon cycling."
For more information on this research see: Global burn severity in forest ecoregions: trends, climate drivers, and predictive insights. npj Natural Hazards, 2025,2(1):1-13. The publisher for npj Natural Hazards is Nature Portfolio.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1038/s44304-025-00113-3.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Kang He, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of Connecticut. Additional authors for this research include Xinyi Shen, Emmanouil Anagnostou.

2025 JUN 16 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on environment and natural resources. According to news reporting originating from Bogor, Indonesia, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forest and land fires have become an annual occurrence in South Papua Province over the past decade, with Mappi District identified as a fire-prone hotspot."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from IPB University: "This study analyzes hotspot trends and dynamics from 2012 to 2021 and estimates burned areas using Terra/Aqua Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS)satellite data and ArcMap 10.8. The highest number of hotspots was recorded in 2015 (3,879), with 36.5% occurring on peatland and 63.5% on mineral soils. A historical hotspot analysis pinpoints the prevalence of fire incidents between July and October, highlighting the necessity for intensified prevention measures before July. Furthermore, a significant linear regression is established between annual hotspot numbers and rainfall in Mappi District (p-value = 0.006), signifying the impact of climatic factors on fire occurrences. The largest burned area, estimated at 134,051.74 hectares, also occurred in 2015, coinciding with a strong El Nino event. More importantly, these fires occurred not only on mineral soil but also on peatland areas."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Hence, this study highlights the critical need to prioritize comprehensive forest and land fire management in Mappi District, South Papua Province."
For more information on this research see: Forest Fire Dynamics Over a Decade in Mappi District, South Papua: Hotspot Trends and Burned Areas Estimation Using MODIS Data. Journal of Natural Resources and Environmental Management, 2025,15(3). (Journal of Natural Resources and Environmental Management - http://journal.ipb.ac.id/index.php/jpsl). urn:contentItem:6GMG-RFH3-S6GH-N05B-00000-00The 'gray' August of Jesus and rural tourism entrepreneurs due to the fires: "People are afraid to travel".2025-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:18ZLexisNexisThe 'gray' August of Jesus and rural tourism entrepreneurs due to the fires: "People are afraid to travel".


Jesús and his wife own two rural lodgings located in the interior of the mountains of León: one of them in La Omañuela, in the heart of the Omaña-Luna Biosphere Reserve, and the other in the municipality of Benllera. For more than two weeks they have been following with concern the evolution of the fires, which have already devastated 7% of the total area of the province and burned more than 100,000 hectares, according to estimates of the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).


As Jesús himself assures in a conversation with this newspaper, he and his wife are "privileged". During the wave of fires, they have had no personal injuries. They have not lost their properties and they have not had to be evacuated because of the fires. However, they are indirectly affected. As well as the rest of the entrepreneurs of the rural tourism sector, the other great victim of the fires.
While Spain faces the year with the mind set on beating a new record of tourists -the forecast is to reach 95 million and exceed last year's figure-, rural areas have experienced a 'gray August' as a result of last-minute cancellations. In the absence of final data for this month, the reality is that the big cities have once again seen their streets crowded with tourists this summer during the month of July. In Madrid, overnight stays have grown by 1.13% compared to the same month in 2024. The same happened in Barcelona, which gained 5.58% of tourists in July. And also in Malaga, which has surpassed its figures of last year, receiving 671,000 travelers.
And although rural areas have also experienced the first months of summer with very positive data as far as tourism is concerned, the truth is that the month of August has been very different from what they expected. "What should have been a summer with 100% occupancy, we have noticed a significant decline, especially in the areas closest to the fires," explains Jesús del Río, owner of two rural lodgings and national secretary of ACETUR (Spanish Association of Rural Tourism). As he explains to this newspaper, entrepreneurs linked to the rural tourism business have been indirectly affected from minute zero.
"Since the big fires started in León, around August 15, even a little before, everything was cancellations. People are afraid to travel, they are uncertain about going to a destination that they are telling you is burning, that they are evacuating and that the air quality is not good," he assures.
The two outbreaks that originated a few kilometers from the areas where their rural lodgings are located have made the daily life of Jesús and his wife an endless number of last-minute cancellations. "We are encountering people who are due to arrive tomorrow or the day after and cancel. And people who are in the accommodation and tell you they don't want to stay because they don't want to get up in the morning and not know if they have to leave or stay. They prefer to shorten their vacation and leave," he says.
During the key days -especially the weekend of the August 15 national holiday-, rural accommodations in the most affected areas were completely empty. "We are talking about a 100% cancellation rate, especially in the affected territories. If I am going to go to stay in Las Médulas and they are telling me that they are evacuating, it doesn't make any sense. I cancel and leave," Jesús explains.
And not only that. In addition to the economic losses caused by last-minute cancellations, there is the uncertainty of what will happen in the coming months. And the fact is that, as Jesús himself assures, there are already tourists who are canceling trips they had scheduled for the autumn. "What we are noticing is that these mid-term reservations, for mid-September, October and Christmas, you wake up in the morning and receive the free cancellation message," he adds.
In spite of the bad figures with which they have closed August, businessmen like Jesús are hopeful that the situation will improve in the coming weeks. And the fact is that, although they have already registered 50% cancellations of all the bookings they had planned for autumn, the truth is that they believe there is still room for maneuver as it is a very different type of tourism to that of sun and beach. "In rural tourism, they are short-term reservations. For the December long weekend, you can rent two or three months in advance. But the small houses you work with three or four weeks of margin", he assures.
Other affected areas
Looking at the figures for the whole country, between August 1 and 21 alone, a total of 362,473 hectares burned throughout Spain, according to data from the European Commission's Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS). Castilla y León, Galicia and Extremadura have been the three most affected areas. However, there are other areas such as Asturias, Madrid or Castilla-La Mancha that have also seen part of their surface area burned. Some of these affected areas were struggling in recent years to become emerging rural destinations in terms of tourism. However, now they have had to face a wave of fires that has jeopardized their present and near future.
José Fernando Beltrán is the president of the Asociación Montaña Palentina Turismo Vivo. The area of Montaña Palentina has an area of 78,600 hectares, of which about 3,000 have been burned in recent weeks as a result of fires. As he assures, it is a very small part of the territory. However, it has been enough so that many businessmen have also suffered last minute cancellations as a consequence of the fires originated in the area.
"We estimate that 30% of the reservations have been cancelled prior to the client's arrival. During the stay, there have been customers who have decided to leave the accommodation. It was no longer just the fire itself, but also the smoke. The smoke has moved to many places and has reached people who were on vacation or who wanted to spend a few days in peace and quiet," he explains.
According to what Fernando told this newspaper, the year was going very well. In fact, the association estimates that the figures were around 25% higher than last year. However, the fires in nearby areas have paralyzed this increase in bookings during the month of August and has installed a sense of uncertainty about what may happen in the coming months. "We don't have figures for October, but in September there have already been some cancellations," he says.
In spite of everything, the sector remains optimistic. Fernando hopes - like Jesús - that the situation will improve. "When the information surfaces and it is seen that few hectares have been burned, the public will not be so reluctant and the public will return to Montaña Palentina as a destination," he says. A very similar reflection to the one that Jesús launches from his rural lodging. And, as he explains, although almost 8% of the surface of the province has been burned, there is still 92% left to visit.
"It is true that now is not the best time to see Las Médulas, because they are black. Nor is it the best time to see Picos de Europa or Fasgar. Is it dangerous to come to León? Yes, if you go to those areas where they are evacuating and where the air quality is bad. But the rest of the areas of the province are feasible. There is still an area free of fires and susceptible to be visited and discovered", he says.

A major forest fire consumed at least eight houses in the municipality of Toro Toro, north of Potosí, and left as a result the death of a woman who was trying to protect her home, informed the mayor of that region, Hernán Colque.


"There are eight houses that have been burned. We have a deceased person who wanted to protect her home; she did not succeed and lost her life on the spot. The lady was a single mother, she had nine children. The community is in mourning", confirmed Colque on Bolivia TV.
The mayor indicated that the fire started on Saturday night in the community of Mojon K'asa and the causes are still under investigation. The fire has not yet been controlled.
The fire spread rapidly in the area and affected mainly areas of pine, eucalyptus and other native species, reaching more than 8,000 hectares.
Fire
"The fire has almost affected around 8,000 hectares (...) We are taking measures to declare an emergency. There are between 28 and 30 families affected," Colque said.
According to the departmental police commander, Fernando Barrientos, agents from the Toro Toro police station went to the site on Saturday to verify the incident.
The victim's daughter reported that the woman had been hit by the flames while trying to control the fire.
In addition to the destroyed houses, heavy losses in crops and damage to local ecosystems are reported.
Due to the magnitude of the fire, the Command in Chief of the Armed Forces deployed 50 soldiers from the 18th Victoria Regiment of the CITE, under the command of 10 instructors, who were transferred to the community of Mojon K'asa, epicenter of the fire.
The objective of the deployment is to contain the advance of the fire, protect the surrounding communities and prevent further damage to the protected area's biodiversity.
During the early hours of Monday morning, dozens of villagers also joined the containment efforts.
On Sunday, the Vice-Ministry of Civil Defense reported seven active "fires" in Santa Cruz and 855 hot spots scattered in six departments.
